author: ThiniT

description.text:
I'm not sure if this puzzle is easier or harder than its spherical predecessor; please let me know what you think.  The internals have been tweaked now so that the outside does not have any major divots.  One nice thing about the ellipsoidal shape is that this puzzle won't roll away.  
The OpenSCAD file is parameterized to easily customize this design.  One way to make it significantly harder is by reducing the tolerance for a tighter fit.  You can also view the assembly as an animation to see an exploded view of the parts.

Print three each of the right and left pieces.  The multiply feature in skeinforge is handy for this.  These print great with zero infill; I use two extra shells and can print all six pieces in less than 1.5 hours on my TOM.

This is a replacement inner axis cap for the Ultimaker.  It is very similar to PabloBell's nutless axis nut that was derived from MoonCactus' design.  The key difference in this design is that I added hexagonal extension that contains a standard hex nut (press-fit).

I printed PLA, 0.2 mm slice, 0.8mm wall, 30% fill.  
I used a screw to press the nut into the hexagonal protrusion.  A pliers might work just as well.  Basically, you want to install the nuts before installing the axis cap.

comments.text: Thanks
comments.author: iSuat

comments.text: Very elegant. And these caps look nicer too. I guess you can tighten them as much as you like without fear of braking the thread. And these holes don't need to be threaded, which is some effort after all. But I was wondering, did you try my Nutless Axis Caps and did they get loose with time?
comments.author: PabloBell

comments.text: Thanks.  Yes, you can tighten without worrying about stripping the plastic.  In standard Ultimaker, that generally wouldn't be a problem because the screws don't need to be very tight, but I have direct-drive setup and I need to make certain the steppers don't loosen up (they use the same screws as the axis caps).  I also use nylon locknuts for a little extra security.  I didn't actually install your Nutless Axis Caps for that reason, but I did appreciate the "open" C-shape design that allows for installation/removal without fussing with the shafts.  Also, not having to mess around with trying to hold the nuts in position is a real hassle - that was another aspect that I liked about your design.  So many good ideas out there!
comments.author: PabloBell

comments.text: Now I see the need for the extra security. And BTW, the open C shape was MoonCactus idea. And you should install his banana blocks ;)
comments.author: jwags55

comments.text: Amazing how many variants exist for these caps (i.e. how annoying are the stock ones)! Yours is probably the best mashup so far imho :)

title: 5mm Hex (Allen) Wrench for Bicycle Disc Brakes

description.text:
This is a small finger wrench I designed to adjust the Disc Brakes on my Trek DS Tektro Novela Disc brakes.

As the pads wear I find that I need to adjust the stationary pad which requires a 5mm hex wrench. Because the spokes get in the way, trying to use a regular long handled 5mm hex wrench (or combination wrench) was a huge pain.

This design easily fits into the available space and allows you to quickly and precisely adjust the distance between the fixed brake pad (the one that does not move when you press your brake lever) and the rotor.

I made mine using PLA but ABS would work just as well. If you make one, especially for another bike/brake system or another purpose entirely I would appreciate a comment. I'm providing the FreeCad file so you can modify the shape/size as needed to fit your application.
No special instructions. Prints directly from stl with no modifications.

Old TR himself laid the cornerstone of this magnificent arch in 1903. It served for years as the North entrance of Yellowstone National Park. Custom mount for iPhone 6 that uses the CD player slot in Ford C-Max to hold the phone at an easy height for using as a GPS.

Be sure to check out version 3.0.3 - that is my latest and best fit.

I started off with a solid mount that the phone would slide into, but after my first prototype, I realized that two much smaller pieces would be quicker to printer and easier to maintain.

I ended up cutting some cardboard and taping it together to get the rough angles and then printing a couple partial models to test for fit and angles.

Eventually I arrived at the current design. Because the iPhone6 has the camera stick out 0.7 mm I had to add slots.

The latest design (3.0.3) fit perfectly for me without feeling too tight or too loose. I glued (testing simple white glue) the non-slip shelf liner to the base.

You may need to dip the curved hooks into very hot water and tighten or loosen the fit to your phone. You will also want to use a non-slip shelf liner between the mounts and the car as PLA is very slick and with enough acceleration you can get the mounted phone to slide out, which is a bad thing.

comments.text: My next iteration will be thinner and may try to tilt the phone toward the driver some.

author: francesca2004

description.text: A mixture of the Amsterdammertje (by niekmarks on the untitled-scene-13 and untitled-scene-13_fixed.obj's [I used the HSA trophy version]), the customizable Movie award by The New Hobbyist, the Saxxy base by bogart27 and Valve Software, a rescaled Nespresso Pilon from GrabCad, and (not listed, but wanting to give credit,) nicklievendag's Oscar (Please let him know that I have no malicious intent towards your work, so I will license it as Creative commons share-alike, to keep it LGPL safe. I'm sorry, but I only used the base of all of them, and yours was stretched and hidden. I did not use the full work for "trophy2_fixed.obj", but I did on the ones with internal faces. Don't worry, I won't do it commercially, but I need my current license to cooperate with others's [who I used more of.] license,and to 3d print it on shape ways. Sorry.) "trophy2_fixed.obj" has a low enough polygon (count: 27k), edge (???), and vertex (13.5k) count to work on Valve's Source Engine as a prop/bodygroup/weapon. It will not work for a weapon for TF2, or as a hat without simplification, which I can't do correctly in mesh lab. "trophy2.obj" is too large to do this. Both can be subdivided and smoothed correctly, while keeping details. This involves Catmull-clark, midpoint-edge, normals fiddling (if needed), and surface-preserving laplacian smoothing. I tried to blend all design aspects together with even distortion, and I have another version without the Oscar with a no-derivatives license, (if you want it up, let me know in advance, Ok. It will also have less polygons, and might even work for HL1/QUAKE. Keep that in mind.) Credit to the movie industry and Valve Software for the nice models that were remade by those I credited. Some models have internal geometry, and may not be printable. Also, all models need rescaling to print on shape ways or sculpteo. It can be found on my dropbox, which I need to organize, so you can get the file.

Clara.io, Meshlab, Blender, and Customizer/openscad. Meshlab's split connected components will produce layers containing variations, of which certain parts that are not individual components can be cut off using the select faces in region and delete selected faces/vertecies. This only applies to "untitled-scene-13.obj."
This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc04ce8738b0b15

I remixed the source to give it a personalize stand AND
I cut the lower part in 2, for non-support printing.

So now a bit of glue is needed.

Please LIKE before collecting

Thomas

description.text:
Time for a blast from the past! In honor of Steven Colbert taking over the Late Show, I figured it was high time to update the head gears I made of him to the newer screwless version (I always felt bad about putting holes in his head).

I can't believe it's been more than four years since the original was on his show (for all of a few seconds). How many of you remember his interview with Bre? Here it is, for old time's sake: http://www.cc.com/video-clips/yvz8wj/the-colbert-report-bre-pettis

Having been involved from before 3D printing really took off, I can say with confidence that Colbert's interview was what launched 3D printing into the mainstream press. It's never been the same since, and I'm glad, especially as this is now my career. Thanks Steven!

Print one of each part and eight pins. Assemble. That's the tricky part, so just think of it as a puzzle and keep trying positions until it looks like the head of Steven Colbert.

I printed this one in Silver PLA on an Ultimaker 2, which I am really impressed by. The quality is extremely good, and I could print the four biggest parts in one job, where it made them sequentially.

comments.text: Wow... that seems so long ago now! Thanks!

title: Stronger Roller Carriage Stabilizer for Kossel Mini 800

description.text:
Same as the Roller carriage stabilizer for Kossel 800, but modified to improve the overall strength of the part, specifically by improving the surface area of the lower horizontal layers. This remix also removes the part's built in support material, so you can generate your own support material with your slicer.

Version 1.1 contains some additional reworking of the model with some extra support on each side.

Extra parts you may need:

6 x ∅19mm Nylon Roller Wheel with M6 Thread Shaft
6 x Metric Thread M6 x 30mm 304 Stainless Steel DIN912 Hex Socket Head Cap Screw Bolt (or other M6 x 30mm bolt, but these ones are cool)
9 x Metric Thread M6 304 Stainless Steel Hex Full Nut (or Flange Nuts if you want a bit more grip and you're into that sort of thing)

Filament: Taulman 910 Alloy at 250 degrees C.

Hotend: E3D V6 4mm nozzle

Bed: Smooth glass, PVA mix, heated to 55 degrees C for all layers.

Slicer: Slic3r 1.2.9

Speeds: auto speeds with 60mm/s max, 60mm/s bridges, 20mm/s gap fill. First layer forced to 20mm/s.

Layers: 0.3mm layer height for all layers. First layer has 200% extrusion width.

Infill: Honeycomb, 25% infill density. Rectilinear on top and bottom. 20% perimeters/infill overlap.

Support Material: Auto overhang threshold, 0.2mm contact distance, pillar configuration, 2.5mm pattern spacing, 1mm interface pattern spacing, 3 interface layers. Don't support bridges.

Brim: 5mm brim for extra adhesion.

author: stgiga

description.text: end stop prusa i3 steel

An adjustable, re-configurable, and customizable head mounted display for hobbyists and prototyping. many of the parts can be changed or customized to fit different electronics and optics without re-printing the entire build.

This configuration is designed to fit a Samsung Galaxy S4. If you are using another phone you may need to change the Phone Plate part to fit your device. Use the phone plate template for this.

you will need to buy or acquire lenses for this project. the lens plate is designed to use 45mm lenses in single or dual setup. the lens plate v2 is designed to use 38mm lenses, or a combination of 38mm and 45mm lenses. The lenses are held in place with clear epoxy set into the notches on the lens holders. If you are using some other lenses, you may need to make your own lens plate, use the lens plate template for this.

you will also need some rubberbands, as they hold your phone in the phone plate, and a strap if you intend to use one.

when printing the set screws you may need to scale them up or down depending on your printers configuration and settings. (mine worked better after scaling up 5%)

you will need to print 22 parts to fully assemble this project:

1X mask plate
1X mid plate
1X phone plate
1X lens plate (either v1 or v2 depending on your lenses)
1X strap arms (optional) (these have floating parts, use supports)
8X set screws
4X set screws (optional)

you only need to print the strap arms and the screws for them if you intend to use a head strap. the "top" of the strap arms have a small indicator as they are only meant to fit on one way.

the plates are designed to slide on the rails of the corresponding plate, except for the lens plate which snaps into the mid plate. you can adjust these for comfort and lens focus. when everything is lined up correctly, tighten the set screws to keep the plates in place.

comments.text: You should make some silicon filled pressure lenses too, that would make this assembly the most customizable yet!

description.text: This is a simple solution to avoid purchasing expensive automatic soap refills for the Lysol Automatic Soap Dispenser.

• Print 2 Plugs.
  • Drill 2- 1/4 inch holes in the top of the refill cartridge
  • Find or print a small funnel
  • Refill the cartridge with any liquid hand soap
  • Use the plugs to plug the holes after refilling.

title: Rubik's cube for the blind (fully printable)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Check the comments for a video!!! A Rubik's cube with patterned faces distinguishable by touch, so it can be solved by a blind or blindfolded person.
It is fully 3D printable, requiring no screws or springs.

More detailed instructions and pictures here:
http://myshumi.net/2011/07/07/cube-for-the-blind-3d-printed/ Tools: 3D printer super glue sandpaper Parts to print: UPDATE (22/07/2011): I put all the pieces together in 6 plates, so you can print one of each plate if you want ;) 1 corner with each pattern (8 in total; corners are printed at once) 1 edge outer part with each pattern (12 in total; each edge outer part will be glued to an edge inner part) 12 edge inner parts (all the same) 1 center outer part with each pattern (6 in total; each center outer part will be combined with a center inner part and a center core) 6 center inner parts (all the same) 6 center core parts (all the same) 1 core Instructions: The cube has the following 6 patterns on its faces: dots, stripes, plain, pyramid, circle and hole. Start by printing the corners, they are already properly patterned, so just print one of each and you're done with the corners. Then let's print the edges. Because of the patters, I couldn't find a way to print the edges at once like with the corners, so each edge is printed in two pieces. Print one of each edge outer piece, each one has 2 face patterns on them. Then print 12 edge inner parts. Now glue each inner and outer part, and you got your edges. (I suggest you sand with a rough sandpaper each surface which will be glued, so they adhere better) At this point I placed all my edges and corners on my C4U's core to see if everything was ok. I checked the patterns and the way the pieces fit together. Now you'll want to sand the parts of the pieces that touch each other so you can make the cube move more smoothly. They probably won't get perfect, so be careful how much you are sanding or you might open holes on your pieces. Now to the centers. Each center piece is printed in 3 parts - outer, inner and core. Only the outer has patterns, so each one of the 6 outer centers will be different. Then print 6 center_inners and 6 center_cores. Not to need screws, this cube rotates with a cone inside a chamber. the chamber is formed by the inner and outer parts. Before assembling the centers, sand the surfaces which will touch others, especially the inside walls of the hole on the inner part and the (head) of the core so they slide better against each other. To put each center together, you will put the core through the inner part (it only enter right one way) and glue the outer part on top of the inner part trapping the core inside the chamber. Be careful not to glue the core to the other parts, or it won't rotate. If you did it for all 6 centers and they are rotating, you are almost there! The core is simply a little cube where all 6 centers will be glued to. Be very careful with the core, it is tiny and the makerbot's resolution doesn't make a cube as even as desired (for me at least). You'll want it to be as even as possible, so your cube rotates well (mine was initially bent and one of the faces didn't rotate nicely). First, to check if everything is ok, glue two adjacent centers (make sure they go along the whole cube's pattern arrangement) to the core as in the picture and try to fit an edge through them. If it enters without effort and gets trapped by the center caps, your cube is doing well. Glue all the other centers to the core, being careful with the arrangement of the patterns (check the corners and edges for that, and make sure pyramid is the opposite to stripes, hole is the opposite to plain and circle is the opposite to dots). Now you just assemble the cube like in a regular Rubik's cube. for those who don't know how to, you can easily find a quick tutorial on youtube. And now you got your fully printed patterned cube!

title: wall mount for logitech ex110 keyboard

description.text: I have either have too much junk on my desk or too small a desk, so I don't have room for my keyboard. That's why I made this thing - to hang my keyboard on the wall! It uses the hole intended for a keyboard clip/riser on the back of the keyboard. I never used my "riser", which is good, since it broke years ago. I used RB1205s replacement for the original keyboard clip (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:88174) as a template for size and everything.

Print. Use screw to attach to wall. One is enough to hold the keyboard, but use two if you want it hanging horizontally.  
I printed PLA with 0.4 infill, but I think you could go lower than that. 0.4 mm layer height worked fine.

Ridgid 12 volt battery holder

The diameter of this version should give 38 centimeters OD, and each layer (out of 3) is 40 degrees of a 120 degree turn 19 centimeters high each. That comes out to a 57cm high turbine. I'm hoping that the size is sufficient to drive a small axial flux turbine to further the development.
For the rotating assembly you need:
  • 9 Blades 32cm diameter
  • 12 arms
  • 4 center hubs
  • 1 center hub top for your bearing size, insert bearing
  • 1 center hub top end cap
  • 1 rotor mount for your bearing size, insert bearing
  • cut 65cm of 22mm galvanised Central heating pipe
    Putting these together:
  • Mount the 22mm heating pipe into the rotor hub, it fits very snug.
  • Mount the center hubs about evenly spaced on the 22mm tube
  • The top normal center hub is upside down, the center hub top with the bearing sits flush on it.
  • Mount the 12 arms with M4 nuts and bolts onto the center hubs
  • Mount the blades with M4x16 bolts to the arms, start top.
    For the threaded rod/shaft mount:
  • 1 stator mount
  • 1 Surface mount (optional)
  • 1 threaded rod axle guide
  • 1 meter of M10/M16 threaded rod
    Putting it together:
  • Mount the stator mount at 70cm from the top, clamp down with nut.
  • Put the aluminium tube into the surface mount, screw that too a small wooden plate or such to make it easier to work on.
  • Thread 1 of the Axle guides onto the threaded rod. One nut goes in the bottom, another with a washer on top. Add M4 with bolts and nuts if you want to use the clamp method instead.
  • I grip the rod in the electric drill to speed up threading the axle guide on the rod because i'm lazy. This only works for M10 :)
  • Slot the assembly into the aluminium tube, clamp the top flange onto the tube.
    You can now slide the rotating assembly over the threaded rod, use a Nyloc nut to keep it there. Put the top end cap over it to keep the rain out.
    I should totally make a build video!

The Stargate DHD clock will display the time using NeoPixel LED’s oriented around a simulated clock face. The clock provides an hourly and half hour chime that can be turned on and off. The hours and minutes can be set via pushbuttons located on rear of the clock base. The center crystal on the DHD clock will illuminate on the hour and half hour for one minute. The illumination of the crystal is provided via a color changing RGB LED.

The hour is represented by a NeoPixel LED changing to red, the minute is represented by a NeoPixel LED changing to green and the seconds are represented by the NeoPixel LEDs changing to a blue color as the second’s increment. Using this method, reading the clock is very intuitive. As the seconds increase, each LED will change to a blue color. The Red (Hour) or Green (Minute) LEDs will not be overwritten by the Blue seconds LEDs.

The clock is 3D printed and utilizes one Arduino UNO, four NeoPixel rings and a real time clock.

The .stl files for printing the clock parts and the Arduino Uno code are located here and can also be found at www.guarnero.com.

The 3D clock dial and base are based upon the work of Techno35 at

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49627

The dhd (dial home device) dial was resized so that it can print on a Lulzbot Mini printer and the dhd (dial home device) base was resized and heavily modified to provide a housing for the electronics.

The .stl files include the dial, base, ring sections for mounting the NeoPixels, crystal LED mount/cover, base cover and the crystal lens. The entire clock was printed with HIPS filament with the exception of the crystal lens which was printed with clear ABS. The clock is painted so any color filament will suffice.

A complete parts list along is provided at the end of this document.
Stargate Clock Operation

A small, obviously scalable, U-Joint. printed in ABS with 3mm walls and 10% infill on my Ultimaker 2. Instead of using the normal Cura support I used my own which can simply be combined with the file (you can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:991392)

The picture shows two u-joints glued together with an axle inside for strength.

-The axle size for the unscaled .stl is ~5/16" (~8mm) in diameter
-The tiny whole going through the axle is for a cotter pin <1/16" (2mm) in diameter (rebar tie wire is perfect)
-The bolts used to hold the joint together are 3/16" (~4mm)
Just because of imperfections and expansion of plastic when printing it may be necessary to use a drill bit to make the wholes the right size. I used the same ABS juice that I use on my print bed to glue the nuts in just to make them harder to loose.

A DIY Canon RC-6 IR Remote. It seems to work from ~5 feet. The case is semi-parametric. As it is, it fits (mostly) nicely in the hand. (The back end could be a little smaller...) Circuit and code based on design at http://www.doc-diy.net/photo/eos_ir_remote

Measure your components and make sure they'll fit in the case.  Print top, bottom, button.  Fit electronics, test, and glue the top to the bottom. (By using superglue, prying it apart is pretty easy.)
I sanded the top/bottom and sprayed some plasti-dip to give it a semi-rubberized surface. (I think I liked the pre-sanded feel better.)
Code is for an ATtiny13 chip.  The code builds to 717 bytes, which fits nicely.  I simplified the circuit to only a 3V button battery, a switch, an IR LED, and the ATtiny13.
The push-switch is scavenged from a musical-greeting-card, as were the battery contacts.
Boosting to 6V doesn't increase the range all that much.  As the battery can only source ~20mA, the addition of a capacitor might improve distance.
Fitting and hot gluing all the components takes some finagling; try not to burn yourself.

I have never had a soprano saxophone. I had the insane idea that I might print a soprano saxophone cone in sections and experiment with boring holes in it and so on to see what I might come up with, so I printed a small section of the top of the cone where the mouthpiece connects, but I needed a mouthpiece to see if it was going to work.

I discovered a wealth of information on the site http://sax.mpostma.nl/EN/ which has a lot of measurements that are really useful on existing saxophones and mouthpieces.

I used this site to create a mouthpiece using freecad to rough out the chamber dimensions, then filled out around it with something I think is a fair shape for the mouthpiece. If you print this, get a thumbscrew at your local hardware store for the ligature, then print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46980 (the soprano reed) you will be able to have a fully printed soprano mouthpiece.

Also on https://www.youmagine.com/designs/soprano-saxophone-mouthpiece-with-ligature

For the first print, I used ABS at .2mm layer height and 20% fill and .8mm shell.

While I used ABS for the mouthpiece and ligature, I have found that the mk2 reeds in ABS at 1mm are extremely soft to play so you may want to use PLA on the reed to make it more brittle. I have not tried a bigger layer height, so maybe that will work as well.

The ligature should absolutely be printed in ABS, as it needs to flex a fair bit to tighten around the reed and mouthpiece.

comments.text: You may design and print keyless soprano sax (https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/5731207165 ). But for the mouthpiece and reeds I prefer regular ones. Or you need a skill of mouthpiece refacing.

UPDATE: New design for the more common 'round' cameras see the NLFCM_R_V1 file.

Do you have a Nissan Leaf and wish you had a front camera like the Tekna does? Well you’re in luck, as I have developed a precisely fitting mount for a standard wireless car reversing camera. The wireless camera kit costs about £20 on ebay, then you can duplicate the great rear camera system for the front, all without permanently modifying the car at all, so great for if you’re leasing the Leaf.

If you don't have a 3D printer but would like one, please leave a comment :)

What I describe here will be following the order of the pictures.

2) First you’ll need a camera, I based the design on a common camera than can be bought in a wireless kit for about £20. You’ll also need a screen if your kit didn’t come with one, but I had one spare. I’m assuming you’ll be OK to connect this. Below are a few links, with examples with the camera and wireless kit, for reference, I don’t sell these, these are just a few examples of the same type.

Camera (square): http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/170-CCD-Car-Front-Side-Camera-Vehicle-HD-Color-Waterproof-Reverse-Camera-Kit-/271359072528?hash=item3f2e42d910

OR camera (round): http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/291552705393 or http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/231558568622

Wireless kit:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Wireless-Kit-170-CCD-Car-Front-Side-Camera-HD-Color-Waterproof-Reverse-Camera-/271691370299?hash=item3f42114f3b

Screen (you may also wish to attach a car 12V connector to plug it in with): http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/371230987620

3-4) Download the .STL file. I printed on the Hobbyking Fabrikator on 0.2mm layer with 10% infill using Craftware 1.11 beta with blue 1.75mm PLA filament , and it printed well. I suggest printing in the stock orientation, i.e. with one of the arms at the bottom, and this provides the best strength for the part (due to layer direction).

5) I found the best support settings for craftware to be as shown in image 3. If you’re using other software then your mileage may vary. Printing takes about an hour for me, so you may want to look at further steps to prepare.

6-7) Protect the Leaf with some sticky tape, as whatever material you print with can easily scratch the car.

8) Once the print is finished remove all the support materials using pliers or a knife. Insert the camera’s cable through the hole at the back of the mount and then slide it into the mount, it should be a tight friction fit. Thread the cable through the hole at the front and push the wire into the groove.

9-11) Test fit the mount on the Leaf, if it doesn’t fit flush, like 9) then you may need to adjust the cable in the groove.

12) I would suggest routing the cable as shown, securing with cable ties, it will not catch on anything, or be in the way when charging.

13-14) Internal wire routing to main 12V battery, be careful to observe polarity when connecting to 12V battery, red to positive, black to negative. I added a switch to allow the camera to be switched off if the car is being left for long periods of time (weeks) although for short periods it doesn’t matter as the Leaf keeps the 12V battery charged.

15-17) By this stage I’m assuming it all fits and the camera works. If so, open the charge port and connect up your screen. angle the camera so with the charge port open you can just see the number plate (white line) I find this a very good reference point for the front of the car. Once you’ve adjusted it and tightened the screw on the camera to secure it at that angle, close the charge port lid, and you should get a view with about ¼ bumper and ¾ road. The idea is that for normal parking it will work fine, but for very close parking you can open the charge port cover and voila, an even better reference point!

18) A few prototypes during development… :)

19-20) An example of just how close you can now confidently get to another car or object.

I hope this works well for you, if you have any problems, please leave a comment, and I’ll try to assist. Enjoy!

Thanks for reading all this, in the works is a mount for the screen in the car, and other camera possibilities...

The brewing stand from Minecraft with separate potions. Just a fun, cute little model. I tried to paint mine with some Krylon, but it didn't turn out too well.

The potion requires a raft and supports to print, I used a .2 layer height but anything else should be ok. The stand was actually a little trickier than i thought it would be. It definitely needs supports and any layer height is good. But depending on your printer you may need to do something that I've never really done before, and that's increasing the support density. As it was printing the separate towers near the potion rings, I noticed that the posts would buckle back and forth, making it almost impossible for them to print correctly. The supports weren't enough for it, and with no solid attachment they suffered a lot of backlash so make sure to watch for that. Enjoy, and please post a make if you can!

title: Rostock Max EZStruder Top Plate Mount and Spool Holder

description.text:
This is a minimal mounting system to move your EZStruder to the top of Rostock Max. Routing all the wires is still up to you.   
The spool holder will also fit the small 1lb Taulman spools.

You'll need 6 M4 bolts and nuts to attach it to the top plate.   
There are three spots on the top of the printer where the extruder and the spool can be mounted. You'll probably want to mount the spool in the spot that you consider the front of your printer. That'll leave the other two spots for mounting the extruder(s).  The filament passes through the center hole when it goes from the spool on top to the extruder underneath and the least "kinky" route means that the spool and the extruder should not be mounted on top of each other. But a spool can be mounted over a different extruder (like in a dual extruder setup).   
I printed both with two shells and 25% infill. That was enough for the extruder mount but the spool post probably needs something a little more solid.

Who doesn't love Minions! Print out this Minion spool holder today! It's really simple to assemble and paint! It can hold one single spool of filament.

First, print out two Minions, two backstops, and one base. The supporting boxes on the corners of the base are hollow! Make sure to have supports on! Also, the base is there to space the Minions out and to add some height to the holder so the spool doesn't rub the ground. Glue a backstop on to each Minion. Then glue the supports of the base underneath the backstops. Then get a PVC pipe that is no bigger than 4 cm in diameter (the entire diameter, not just the hole in the middle).

If you want, you can paint the Minions like I did! I used a white primer then acrylic paint. I recommend painting before any gluing.

Use your Gopro mounts with a standard camera that has a tripod mount.

I made this so I could use my camcorder with all my GoPro mounts.

You will need a 1/4-20 hex head bolt 1/2" long and a 1/4-20 nut.

Print one of each of the 2 parts. Use epoxy to glue the bolt into the main mount, be sure to push it in all the way (screw a nut onto it until dry to hold it tightly in place.

Then epoxy the nut into the finger nut but be sure you don't end up with epoxy in the threads.

Once the epoxy cures, simply screw the finger nut onto the bolt (open nut side facing the mount) and it's ready to use.

Screw the camera onto the bolt until it points the right way, then use the finger nut to tighten the camera down. Now you can attach it to any of your GoPro capable mounts.

title: FrSky D4R-II Tray w/ Folding Antenna Holder

description.text:
FrSky D4R-II stacking 36x36 tray with integrated (print in place) folding antenna tube holders. When extended, antenna leads lock into place at 45deg from the multirotor in the horizontal plane. And when folded, should conform with or into multirotor body. Tray stacks on top of Naze32-type flight controller. Requires antenna tubes... use hot glue (or super glue/CA+) to secure.

Print directions:

  • Tolerances are tight on this, make sure printer isn't over-extruding which will fuse the components together. Lowering extrusion multiplier may help.
  • Print with supports
  • Antenna holder component may fuse to tray due to the tight tolerances. Manually seperate as much of antenna holder as possible, then use flat head to turn the bottom of posts. Expect a "snap" when the rotation post releases from the rest of tray. My success rate wasn't great... maybe 4 out of 6... so print a few extra.

TIP: A little lubrication on the antenna leads will help movement in and out of antenna tube.

This is a remix of the original D4R tray.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:444796

UPDATE: Use v12 for best "print in place" results. Use a pick free the rotating posts (PIC 1). The antenna tube holder portion may be fused to the tray, use a pick to free (PIC 2).

author: Liftedck

title: Frijmags - Custom alphanumeric refrigerator magnets using your handwriting.

description.text:
I made a set of fridge-mags for my daughter for Christmas using my wife's (beautiful) handwriting, which led to this project. I also made a set out of my (poor) handwriting.

If I'm not too lazy to do so when she starts writing herself, I will some day make a new set from my daughter's handwriting every few months to immortalize (assuming I use ABS and not PLA) the progression of her penmanship. We're hoping she gets her mother's calligraphy skills, not her father's.

If you have a 3d printer and some basic tools and supplies, this repo should be enough info to get you from zero to frijmag in around 6 hours. However, if this all sounds neat to you, but you don't really want to do all the stuff below, then fear not! I sell these, custom made from your font template, on Etsy: http://farrisfair.etsy.com.

Recursive, cross-posty links:

  • Rad, awesome Github: https://github.com/JustinFarris/frijmags
  • Yarny, stay-at-home-mommy Etsy: http://farrisfair.etsy.com

Create your font

http://www.myscriptfont.com

  • Download and print this template: http://www.myscriptfont.com/res/ScriptTemplate.pdf
  • Fill out the template in your own handwriting using dark lines, but stay within the guides.
  • You can pick up and relocate your hand for crossed letters and such, but each finished letter should be one single, contiguous object. The magnets will be made using only the upper-case letters to avoid floating objects such as in dotted letters.

Cleanup the images

  • Remove errant pixels, move writing within template guidelines line, etc.
  • Make sure gaps inside letters aren't too small, such as the whole inside the capital "A". Tiny gaps will be auto-filled and disappear when the file is converted to a vector image.
  • Dilate or Erode in gimp as needed to thicken or thin the lines. I also posterized mine since I have an old scanner that doesn't provide very good non-grayscale images. (find a command-line way to do this)

Convert font to TTF: http://www.myscriptfont.com/

  • It would be awesome if we could get the source code for this tool or find an alternative. I have contacted the developer, but no response so far.

Install your font

This is the part that's a little hairy, and you're on your own for parts of it. Below is what worked for me.
YOUR MILEAGE MAY VARY. This is likely to be slightly different on your system than on mine. If this stuff confuses you, perhaps you should find a different DIY project and consider letting me do all of this for you for a reasonable fee via my Etsy shop: http://farrisfair.etsy.com

Put the new TTF font file somewhere safe, such as in ~/fonts/YourFontName.ttf

Add this to /usr/local/etc/ImageMagick-6/type.xml:

  • This can totally be scripted, I just haven't done it yet. 
  <type  
     format="ttf"  
     name="YourFontName"  
     fullname="YourFontName"  
     family="YourFontName"  
     glyphs="/path/to/your/font/file/YourFontNamt.ttf"  
     />

Create text images and SVGs with ImageMagick "convert" and using my mkmags.sh bash script

This is a QAD bash script that uses ImageMagick and a call to API. You can actually use it to make any set of characters, grouped into whatever size batches you want. I'll assume if you've gotten this far that you're comfortable with shell scripts. If not, I'll leave it as an exercise for the maker to either learn or find someone to help out.

Here's what the script does in a nutshell:

  • Takes no arguments, but has several configurable variables up top. You should look a those. It probably won't work if you don't.
  • Allows you to choose what characters to create and how many characters are used per image.
  • Creates a directory to put stuff in.
  • Iterates over the list of characters to create 2d images of $N characters.
  • When all of the 2d images are created, it makes an api call to online-convert.com for each one to convert it to an SVG file. More info at http://image.online-convert.com/convert-to-svg.

I'd rather find an offline script or library to do this. That site/service seems to use potrace on the backend. However, for some reason if I use potrace myself the generated SVGs, while perfectly functional vector graphics files, are not recognized by Tinkercad or a few other offline CAD tools I've tried.

Supposedly autotrace is cleaner and better than potrace, but I had trouble getting it built and installed on my system. I might come back and retry that later.

The free version of the online-convert API only allows 30 conversion jobs per day, so be careful. Do some math to set your variables in mkmags.sh and test. Then test some more. Then test again.

You can also do manual conversions through the website using your browser, and I don't think there's any limitation on that.

It's a pretty useful service, so if you have a legit need for it and can afford it, consider a premium subscription.

Import SVGs to CAD, create STLs

  • Manually add holes the size of your magnets (mine are 1/4" x 1/16" nickel/neodymium discs) to the bottom side of each character.
  • I'm using TinkerCad for this right now, but I'd like to possibly automate it later using OpenSCAD or some other process that finds the largest contiguous area and carves out a hole in the center for the magnet.
  • If you're using all of my defaults, you should import the SVGs to Tinkercad at 20% Scale and 5mm Height.

Time & dimension estimations ~6 hours total:

Writing & scanning template: 5-15min

Edting & cleanup: 5-15 min (maybe more if source image is rough)

Creating images (jpg, convert to svg): 1-5 min

  • (mkmags.sh and/or manual website)
  • Font Size 240

Creating STLs with holes: 20min

  • 5mm thick, 50mm tall, 210mm wide
  • Tinkercad import 5mm tall, 20% scale FIND A WAY TO SCRIPT SVG->STL WITH THESE SETTINGS!
  • Move magnet holes underneath (Cylinder d=6.6mm, h=1.6mm)
  • Export to STL

Printing: ~4-5hrs per set

  • Rotate Y-180deg so no support is needed for the holes
  • I skew it a about 2cm left, because my printer is not well-centered. You should probably calibrate your bot rather than do what I do.
  • Experiment with print settings & speed to bring down time. Let me know what settings you use. I used 20% infill, 3 shells, and 0.3mm layers. Anything higher was better seemed like overkill, and anything worse didn't seem to have the weight you'd want in a fridge magnet.

Assembly: 5-10min per set

I used two methods to affix the magnets (how to they work? IT'S A MIRACLE!), both of which seem to work equally well:

  • Hammer (quicker method): Put a dab of liquid superglue in the hole, and gently place the magnet on top of the hole, then firmly but gently hammer it in with one motion, swiping the hammer to the side before pulling it off the piece to prevent bringing the magnet back up stuck to the hammer.
  • Crimper (less accident-prone method): I have an old Scotchlok crimper that came over on the Mayflower with my dad that worked perfectly for this. Just put a dab of glue in the hole, magnetize the magnet to the inside top of the crimper, and then firmly crimp it into the hole. Again, slide the tool off to the side before pulling it away in case the magnet wants to stay stuck to it.

Needs more research:

  • Common distributions for writing words?
  • Scrabble sets?

Notes & TODOs

  • Automate/script the GIMP filters
  • online-convert.com API key: ~/.online-convert
  • Would be better to find a library to replace the API call to online-convert.com to remove the dependency (API only allows 30 conversions per day)
  • online-convert.com uses potrace, so why doesn't potrace work offline for me? It generates a valid SVG, but the format is not recognized by Tinkercad
  • Use autotrace rather than potrace?
  • Find a way to programmatically find the largest spot for the magnet. OpenSCAD?

This is a super simple thing that you could obviously just design and make yourself. But, I think it's a great tip for people having trouble getting ABS prints to stick to the print bed. You read a lot about people taking bits of old ABS filament and dissolving them in a jar and then spreading that mix on the print bed with a brush. Kind of complicated and dangerous to be storing a jar full of acetone.

My method is to just take a paper towel, dampen it with a bit of acetone and rub it on the slurry dish. Then rub the paper towel on your bed (works best when the bed is cold, before your preheat). This will put a very light coating of ABS plastic on the Kapton tape on your bed. Things stick like crazy.

If I want a thicker coating, then I just put a teaspoon of acetone IN the dish and then rub the paper towel around.

I print a slurry dish in each of my colours of filament. They take about 20 or 30 minutes to print and last for months.

I don't know if you'll find this useful or not, but I sure did. No more curled up edges on large ABS prints.

  • Made tolerances more forgiving for printing on less dimensionally accurate machines

Sextruder V2 is a 100% constrained suspended extruder for delta 3d printers based on the original and awesome design by Justin Edwards (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756426)

comments.text: Has anyone gotten this to work with 3mm filament?  I tried drilling it out for a 6mm tube, but the clearance between the metal gear and the rest of the extruder is still too tight.
comments.author: firebug24k

comments.text: Yes I use it for 3mm filament. I've drilled out where the filament passes through and just put in a larger ptfe connector and tube. Drilling out for the ptfe connectors isn't easy so you might have to rework the file if you don't have some bigger drills. Works great with exactly the same motor as is specified here with the 27:1 ratio and a gearhob that is basically identical. If you make one be sure to line the inside where the filament slides past the idler with ptfe or else the filament wears away the idler and it will start slipping mid print one day when it wears down enough like this: http://i.imgur.com/qu91Zt9.jpg
comments.author: firebug24k

comments.text: Thanks for the info!  I bet I just did a bad job of drilling it out, I'll give it another shot.  I saw yours too, but I already have the NEMA11 motor and want to use it instead of buying another of the bigger motors.  I'll post again after I redo the print.
comments.author: TTN

comments.text: Definitely go with the nema11 motor. I bought one because the nema17 is just too heavy. The geared nema17 sextruder that I posted weights 480grams all up whereas this new one is 210grams all up. which is much better.

comments.text: In regards to retract -- I don't really retract more than 0.9mm or so @ 11.5mm/s, 3500 accel.  You don't need a lot with such a short tube.  On a delta, you're better off having fast travel moves and high travel acceleration (200mm/s+) to make the filament really 'snap' off.  It makes retraction much easier.

Hello players !

Yes, it's just another chessboard but the idea was :

  • Easy to store.
  • Not too material consumer.
  • To have a glossy aspect for the squares.

So I've design it this way and I'm pretty happy of the result.
Of course it's a little bit long to print (around 60 hours - layers of 0.15) but it's fun to built before a game of chess.

You must print :

  • Part n°01 (32 in black & 32 in white). No, really ? (Or in red & green, ok...)
  • Part n°02 (*8... any colors)
  • Part n°03 (*4... any colors)
  • Part n°04 (*4... any colors)

Hope you will enjoy it !

description.text:
when my wife and I bought our house, it had a 1" pipe that was logged in the door to keep people with less than honorable intentions from sliding the open. it looked rough, and was a hastle to keep moving out of the way and kept falling over, I made this so it rotates out of the way when the door is open and sits firmly against the door when in use.

To make this I used a 1' pipe (cut to length of the space between the brace bracket and the door, minus ~.250 (cut to fit desired snugness))
1/4-20 carriage bolt I had laying with a wing nut

A radial bearing toy that can be customized to any size, with any amount of bearings. It can be scaled up to be a bracelet or just stay the same size to play with. This is my first parametric thing so let me know how it works out.

The "Radial Bearing" stl has a support ring for the bearings so support shouldn't be needed.

EDIT: I modified the SCAD file so that now it is better optimized for larger bearing tolerances, heights that are less than the fillet and added a third type of support that supports the individual bearings.

Remove support ring and make sure all bearings can turn freely. It should become easier to turn the more its worked.

When scaling to larger sizes, make sure that there are a lot of bearings so they will keep the center in and not fall out.

The 3D clock dial and base are based upon the work of Techno35 at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49627

The Stargate DHD clock will display the time using NeoPixel LED’s oriented around a simulated clock face. The clock provides an hourly and half hour chime that can be turned on and off. The hours and minutes can be set via pushbuttons located on rear of the clock base. The center crystal on the DHD clock will illuminate on the hour and half hour for one minute. The illumination of the crystal is provided via a color changing RGB LED.

The hour is represented by a NeoPixel LED changing to red, the minute is represented by a NeoPixel LED changing to green and the seconds are represented by the NeoPixel LEDs changing to a blue color as the second’s increment. Using this method, reading the clock is very intuitive. As the seconds increase, each LED will change to a blue color. The Red (Hour) or Green (Minute) LEDs will not be overwritten by the Blue seconds LEDs.

The clock is 3D printed and utilizes one Arduino UNO, four NeoPixel rings and a real time clock.

The dhd (dial home device) dial was resized so that it can print on a Lulzbot Mini printer and the dhd (dial home device) base was resized and heavily modified to provide a housing for the electronics.

The .stl files include the dial, base, ring sections for mounting the NeoPixels, crystal LED mount/cover, base cover and the crystal lens. The entire clock was printed with HIPS filament with the exception of the crystal lens which was printed with clear ABS. The clock is painted so any color filament will suffice.

You can view the entire project at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:991389
Stargate Clock Operating

comments.author: gg2

comments.text: ​I used a 5/32" drill bit but you can use whatever is handy.  If you want, use a 1/8" and work up if the hole is not big enough for the wire.  I think I drilled a 1/16 hole for the mounting base mostly as a screw starter hole.  Just use whatever size will work well with the screws you are using. title: Revised Parts for Nonnef's TARDIS Transformer (at 75% Scale)

description.text:
I printed Nonnef's TARDIS Transformer twice. For the second round I revised a few parts.

Be warned!! I printed at 75% scale and designed my revised parts at that scale! If you are printing the TARDIS full size you will have to scale up to compensate!

The "new inner back brace" has some extra bulk that fills in the loose connection to the sliding upper hips.

The chest pieces and torso back have an angle carved out to accommodate the transformation. I had to dremel out over a millimeter of plastic from the original design before the panel would sit flush in TARDIS mode. You may still need to file a little bit.

The original windows don't survive scaling down. I rebuilt them with thicker panes.

The head is an alternate character, Vector Prime. I was disappointed that I couldn't find Nonnef's VP head, so I made my own in Blender then did some touch-up in TinkerCAD. The screw holes are cut out of the original Soundwave head.

There is also a Sonic Screwdriver which will slot into the hand. The top extends and is held by friction.

There is also a Sonic Screwdriver Cannon and Missile. At the larger scale it could use more detailing, but I'm not going to do any more with that. A "Doctor gun" seems kind of wrong. And anyway I don't care for how it looks with a shoulder cannon, so I'm dropping this as-is.

The Sonic Devices were roughly based on my 10th Doctor's sonic screwdriver pen.

title: Yellowstone's Morning Glory Pool, Underwater Photoscan

description.text:
I realize that the scan isn't much and it isn't printable, but I wanted to share it because it has an interesting feature: All of the scan data which projects below the flat plane is actually underwater. Yellowstone's crystal clear water makes it possible to scan below the water surface using photogrammetry. The scan would have been improved by better lighting (an overcast day would have been better), a polarizing filter (to reduce the reflections on the water) and better access (park visitors are restricted to a boardwalk on one side of the pool).

This technique has great promise because it provides a non-intrusive way to study and document these very delicate and ever changing features. This pool has been greatly altered by visitors throwing objects into it. Having a record of the under water geometry could aid the conservation efforts.

On a technical note it is interesting to contemplate what effect water's different index of refraction has on the geometry produced by the scanning. Even a perfect scan would probably not be geometrically accurate, but would be effective for documenting change over time.

We talked about this and lots more cool stuff on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: Yet another rod/axis end cap (fine-tunable) for the Ultimaker

description.text:
Another tweak to a MoonCactus design.  This design prints the screw, locknut and base.  I use this in conjunction with MoonCactus' Fully parametric bearing-friendly axis caps (non-adjustable).  So I used one of MoonCactus' non-adjustable caps on one end and then my adjustable end cap on the other, but I suppose you could use an adjustable end cap on each end of the rod.  
MoonCactus suggested a shorter threaded component so it doesn't stick out so far, so I've included a shorter version that uses a 6mm hex key to adjust.  
6/6/13 Update: I added two more low-profile components.  AdjThreadSlot.stl and LockNutShort.stl.  The AdjThreadSlot.stl is the shortest of all the screws and the short locknut is 2mm shorter than the original.  You should be able to adjust the slotted screw with either a straight-blade or Phillips screwdriver.   
I should also note that if you like adding grease to the end of the shafts, it is very easy to remove the screw and place some grease on the end of the screw/shaft.  
Although not necessary for this design, I also included my variation of the inner bearing cap (Thing: 99113)  with a hexagonal protrusion that hold the nuts in place.

Base (EndCapThreaded.stl):
0.1mm slice, 0.8mm wall, 30% fill Screw (AdjThread.stl):
0.1mm slice, 0.4mm wall, 100% fill (less fill okay) Locknut (Locknut.stl):
0.1mm slice, 0.4mm wall, 100% fill (less fill okay) Inner Cap (InsideCap.stl):
0.2mm slice, 0.8mm wall, 30% fill
press-fit the nuts into the hexagon protrusion before installing. Remove any "Z scars" on the screw with a knife or fingernail and thread the screw/nut/base in and out enough such that they adjust easily by hand. If they do not thread easily, it will be difficult to accurately set the clearance between the screw and the shaft with the potential to put the axis in a bind. Adjust the screw until it contacts the shaft, and then back it off some (about a 1/4 turn). You don't want to add any additional friction to the system, but merely reduce the axial movement of the shafts. You can also check the clearance by moving the rod back-and-forth until you are satisfied. Use the locknut to keep the screw in the adjusted position, but make certain the screw does not turn while tightening the locknut.

comments.text:
In addition to the advertised purpose, it makes maintenance much more easy.
This is because it allows (dis)assembly of the X/Y rods without touching the bearing cap scew nuts at all (which is a real pain).
I'd recommend to install this on every Ultimaker. Thanks for this great mod!
comments.author: universalist

comments.text: What does this mod allow you to do exactly?
comments.author: adamjvr

comments.text:
robo_kid22,
This modification is to reduce the axial movement of the 8 mm diameter X and Y rods. If you grab the X or Y rod and can move it back and forth "too" much then you may want to install these. How much is too much is entirely up to you, but I think that anything more than 1 mm is too much. Excessive movement can cause the belts to track poorly. This mod allows you to keep the play to a minimum.

remixed_from.author: TimeFramed
remixed_from.title: Toyota truck pop-out window bracket part

description.text:
This is a redesign of my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:165440 - the position of the pin hole was just slightly off, it didn't close the window as tightly as it should; at freeway speeds, it was like have the window rolled down a tiny bit.

So, I moved the pin hole a couple of millimeters, and that did the trick.

And, since that one broke when removing the pin, I also redesigned it to be made of two parts to maximize the strength (to minimize the the reliance on layer bond strength).

The parts should be printed oriented as-is to maximize the parts' strength in the intended axis.

The hole for the pin may be a bit too tight; I used an 11/64 drill bit which made the hole loose enough to hammer the pin in, while remaining tight enough to hold the pin firmly.

I glue the two parts together with superglue (lactate ultra gel control).

title: Acrylic Doors for Flashforge Creator X (or similar Replicator2 Clones)

description.text:
These are a nice set of matching acrylic doors for the Flashforge Creator X style Replicator clones. The doors consist of a left and right side (mirrored), with four low profile 3D printed hinges and a 3D printed latch that holds both doors securely closed. Uses only one latch for both doors. Holds the doors securely closed, and flush with the frame.

Doors are part of a project to enclose our Flashforge Creators to improve print quality. Enclosure includes a snap together Acrylic top, doors, hinges and latch.

We have the kit available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/enclosure-for-makerbot-replicator-2-2x-3d-printers-and-similar-clones/ Includes the front door panels, snap together top hood, made from 3mm Acrylic, hinges and hardware to attach the doors.

Doors can be laserjet cut or routed out of 3mm Acrylic. Print four hinges (two per door), and one latch. Attach hinges to the door with 10mm M3 bolts/nuts, and use the stress relieving printed washers. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755320). With the hinges in place the doors are easy to align for drilling the mounting holes on the printer. Drill the holes and mount on the printer using 16mm M3 bolts/nuts and washers. Enjoy better printing in ABS.

A Plan of Salvation kit to teach with.

I made this for my daughter and then added a second set of word plates in Spanish for my son. My intention is to make this free to everyone to make as I feel it would be inappropriate to sell kits.

Plan of Salvation Kit Printing Instructions

The following instructions detail how I printed my designs on my printer. Modifications and feedback are welcome.

Printer Software: MakerBot Desktop 3.7.0.108
3D Printer: Wanhao Duplicator 4S

Grave

File(s): Grave.stl, GraveSupports.stl
Filament: Black ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The support and grave STL files are oriented coincident to each other. When adding the files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after both files are added select them both and center the group and place the group on the platform and the supports will be in the correct position to fill the inside of the hollow grave. I print both in the same material from the same head. Once the grave is printed, tear out and clean away the supports so that the grave is hollow underneath and a body can be placed inside it while on a table top. I turn on my extruder fan after 30% is completed.

Man Spirit

File(s): ManSpiritV3.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: I turn on my extruder fan after 50% is complete.

Woman Spirit

File(s): WomanSpiritV3.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: I turn on my extruder fan after 50% is complete.

Pre-Existance

File(s): PreExistanceV2.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10% - 30% (10% looks more transparent and 30% more white)
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: I turn on my extruder fan after 50% is complete.

Spirit Paradise and Prison

File(s): SpiritParadiseV2.stl, SpiritPrisonV2.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS and Black ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10% - 30% (10% looks more transparent and 30% more white)
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The paradise and prison STL files are oriented coincident to each other. When adding the files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after both files are added select them both and center the group and place the group on the platform and they will remain in the correct positions relative to each other. You can print paradise in Glow-In-The-Dark White with one extruder and prison in Black ABS with the other extruder. I have oriented the parts to have paradise on the left extruder and prison on the right extruder. OR, you can print both paradise and prison in Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS and just color the prison bars black with a black Sharpe afterwords. I also color the tree green with a Sharpe after it is printed. The paradise STL has a wiper wall around it to help with wiping the black ABS so that it doesn't smear on the white ABS. I turn on my extruder fan after 56% is complete.

Celestial Kingdom

File(s): CelestialKingdomBase.stl, CelestialKingdomSun.stl, 87mmWall.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS and Yellow ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The Base, Sun, and Wall STL files are oriented coincident to each other. When adding the files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after all files are added select them all and center the group and place the group on the platform and they will remain in the correct positions relative to each other. Print the base and wall in Glow-In-The-Dark White with one extruder and the sun in Yellow ABS with the other extruder. I have oriented the parts to have the base and wall on the left extruder and the sun on the right extruder. The wall STL is a wiper wall around the base to help with wiping the yellow ABS so that it doesn't smear on the white ABS. I turn on my extruder fan after 50% is complete.

Terrestrial Kingdom

File(s): TerrestrialKingdomSkyV2.stl, TerrestrialKingdomMoonV2.stl, 87mmWall.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS and Blue ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10% - 30% (10% looks more transparent and 30% more white)
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The Sky, Moon, and Wall STL files are oriented coincident to each other. When adding the files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after all files are added select them all and center the group and place the group on the platform and they will remain in the correct positions relative to each other. Print the sky and wall in blue with one extruder and the moon in Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS with the other extruder. I have oriented the parts to have the sky and wall on the left extruder and the moon on the right extruder. This orientation was not meant to be opposite of the other kingdoms. If you desire to keep your filament loaded in the same extruders as the other kindoms then just rotate the entire assembly 180 degrees on the build plate and then you can keep the Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS in the left extruder and the Blue ABS in the right extruder. The orientation is important so that trails are not left on the finished blue sky when the moon is being printed. The unused extruder drags across the finished sky leaving marks while the moon is being printed with the other extruder. The wall STL is a wiper wall around the sky to help with wiping the Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS so that it doesn't smear on the blue ABS. I turn on my extruder fan after 51% is complete.
I did print this with blue PLA and White ABS and the trick to the mixed PLA/ABS print was to set the build plate to 60C, open the door and remove the top cover, and start with a fresh double coat of hair spray. All else remained the same. The closed door and cover with 110C build plate was too hot for the PLA and it would warp about half way through the print. A 40C build plat was too cool for the ABS wiper wall created by MakerBot Desktop and it would pull loose from the build plate.

Telestrial Kingdom

File(s): TelestialKingdomSkyV2.stl, TelestialKingdomStarsV2.stl, 87mmWall.stl
Filament: Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS and Blue ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 20%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The Sky and Stars STL files are oriented coincident to each other, the Wall STL is not. When adding the Sky and Star files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after all files are added select them all and center the group and place the group on the platform and they will remain in the correct positions relative to each other. After the Sky and Stars is centered then you can add the Wall STL and center it on the build plate. Print the sky and wall in blue with one extruder and the stars in Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS with the other extruder. I have oriented the parts to have the stars on the left extruder and the sky and wall on the right extruder. The wall STL is a wiper wall around the sky to help with wiping the Glow-In-The-Dark White ABS so that it doesn't smear on the blue ABS. I turn on my extruder fan after 49% is complete.
I did print this with blue PLA and White ABS and the trick to the mixed PLA/ABS print was to set the build plate to 60C, open the door and remove the top cover, and start with a fresh double coat of hair spray. All else remained the same. The closed door and cover with 110C build plate was too hot for the PLA and it would warp about half way through the print. A 40C build plat was too cool for the ABS wiper wall created by MakerBot Desktop and it would pull loose from the build plate.

Earth (Mortal Life)

File(s): EarthV2Water.stl, EarthV2Land.stl, 87mmWall.stl
Filament: Green ABS and Blue ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 20%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Notes: The Water and Land STL files are oriented coincident to each other, the Wall STL is not. When adding the Water and Land files to the build plate keep their default positions even if that places them off of the build plate. Then after all files are added select them all and center the group and place the group on the platform and they will remain in the correct positions relative to each other. After the Water and Land is centered then you can add the Wall STL and center it on the build plate. Print the water and wall in blue with one extruder and the land in Green ABS with the other extruder. I have oriented the parts to have the land on the left extruder and the water and wall on the right extruder. The wall STL is a wiper wall around the water to help with wiping the green ABS so that it doesn't smear on the blue ABS. I turn on my extruder fan after 40% is complete.
I did print this with blue PLA and green ABS and the trick to the mixed PLA/ABS print was to set the build plate to 60C, open the door and remove the top cover, and start with a fresh double coat of hair spray. All else remained the same. The closed door and cover with 110C build plate was too hot for the PLA and it would warp about half way through the print. A 40C build plat was too cool for the ABS wiper wall created by MakerBot Desktop and it would pull loose from the build plate.

Man Body

Filament: Blue ABS
Extruder Temp: 230C
Platform Temp: 110C
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%
Raft: Off
Support: Off

Inspiration material for the various pieces

The sun of the Celestial Kingdom is taken from a sun stone on the Palmyra New York Temple.
The moon of the Terrestrial Kingdom is taken from a moon in a stained glass window of the Winter Quarters Temple.
The stars of the Telestrial Kingdom is taken from the stars on the door of the Washington DC Temple.
The tree in the Spirit Paradise is taken from Family Search.
The grave was modified from Tombstones & Grave Markers by Tothe, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:470430

Spanish word plates:
Veil of Forgetfulness = Velo del Olvido
Birth = nacimiento
Death = muerte
Resurrection = Resurrección
Final Judgment = Juicio final

Sketchup 3D text tool parameters for word plates:
Font Arial Black Bold
Center Height 10mm
Filled Extruded 1mm

This fingertip is based on a silicone fingertip which is used by a research group in Brazil (mao3d) for e-nable (enablingthefuture.org) prosthetic hands. I intend to contribute to the project and this is my first prototype using flexible filament (Ninjaflex) to print.

Printed with 0.1mm layer height using 30mm/s speed and support in the hollow circles which was later removed.

It will pass through some tests and will likely have a few iterations because it's good enough for replacing the silicone part.

I have modeled it in OpenSCAD to enable others to improve on my design and also to be easily modifiable to various sizes. In the future, I will probably turn it into a custom or parametric design.

Kudos to Dr. Maria Elizete Kunkel who gave me a sample on which to base and model the part.

• Flexible filament (I used Filaflex)
  • 0.1mm layer height
  • support in the inner circles (use your slicer)

description.text:
Old version of "Belkin Tunebase" had a limit that it supports only iPhone4s or less version of iPhones. If you buy iPhone5 or iPhone6(using lightning cable), it doesn't work anymore.
Of course, Belkin made new version of Tunebase for iPhone supporting lightning cable. As you know, the thing that you buy it means your old Tunebase became a garbage. Because of this, I get this idea from this situation, I would like to share this printable file.

1. You already bought old version of Tunebase.
  2. connect adapter 30pin to lightening cable
  3. print my file and install it

author: openmaya

description.text:
This part is edited from
Minimalistic Mk7 replacement by whosawhatsis http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15718

Part is reinforced at the filament hole, to prevent it to break due to the strong spring force.

This idea came when I went in vacations and I couldn't find a proper solution to cover my toothbrush. Every time when I was using a bag or a glass to hold it, dust or improper utilization of the plastic bag makes the toothbrush to be not used in good hygienic condition.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

top piece with 0.1 and slowly polish it carefully ,

case with 0.2

Project: How acetone has impact on PLA and ABS

Objectives: Learn how PLA and ABS are different in structures

Audiences: This project should be hold only at chemistry lab

Preparation: for each student should be prepared two peaces from toothbrush case in PLA and ABS materials, 100 ml acetone and a bowl of glass

Step 1: Insert PLA toothbrush case in bowl
Step 2: Add acetone until case is covered up
Step 3: Wait for about 10 sec
Step 4: Remove case from the bowl and let it to dry

Repeat steps for ABS case.

Results: Notice how acetone reacts with PLA and ABS, the upper case can be dissolved in ABS while in PLA it can make a smooth contour.

I designed these custom for a friend but because of the expected bulkiness from the printed model, it was a little too large. However the novelty is still there. If anyone wishes to print them; feel free. :)
